hi and welcome you listening to the x-22
report my name is Dave and this is
episode 1557 a and today's date is May
1st 2018 and the top of the episode is
both sides wait for the other to make a
move on the economy let's get into the
economic collapse financial news now we
know around the world the housing market
well it is basically falling apart and
we're seeing signs in many different
countries not just the United States but
other countries we've also seen signs
where the Fed has pushed inflation to
other parts of the world and I believe
that one of these places is Canada
because we've been seeing this housing
bubble being pumped up pumped up and all
of a sudden right now Canada is in
serious trouble and what we're seeing
right now is that the moment of truth
for Canada's all-important housing
market is at hand and the reason for
this is because well we can see rates
are rising banks have been pushing up
mortgage rates and we see also that a
lot of the mortgages they are coming due
and this is going to be a huge problem
and this is also pushing a lot of
individuals out of the market now the
economy has never been as levered as it
currently is in the economy is far more
interest sensitive than has been in the
past to a degree that we don't have
certainty over how each interest rate
hike is going to affect Canadian
consumers all we know is it's going to
be very painful when everything starts
to completely fall apart and here's why
Canada will no longer be able to avoid
the troubling reality of rising rates
the country is entering a period in
which no less than 47% of existing
mortgages need to be refinanced this
year verses 25 to 35% typically and the
pain for Canadian homeowners
appears unavoidable now according to
Statistics Canada total payments on debt
made by the Canadian household rose by
6.7 percent in the fourth quarter from a
year earlier and the interest paid
component climbed 9.2 percent those were
the biggest gains since the financial
crisis and if we look at the UK we can
see we have problems there homeownership
rate for Millennials aged 25 to 34 has
nearly halved in some of the regions of
Britain showing that the housing
affordability crisis extends far beyond
the boundaries of London again what
they've done was they created these
gigantic bubbles they pumped it up and
wages they haven't kept up with
inflation on housing and it pushed a lot
of people out of the market now as you
raise interest rates even more people
are being pushed out of the market and
this is why we said here in the United
States Fannie and Freddie they decided
to basically take the 3% mortgage down
and do a no income check because they're
trying to bring as many people into the
housing market before the whole thing
completely falls apart because what do
these people need to do right now they
need to unload their real estate this is
what happens
they sell when it's very high they buy
when it's really cheap
they sell when it's very high and
basically they unload it right before
everything starts to fall apart it's
almost the same as the stock market
where those institutional investors the
insiders they know they're pumping it up
pumping it up and when it reaches a
certain point they want all the retail
investors in saying Liz's gonna go
higher it's gonna hit a hundred thousand
everyone get in now and they unload
their stocks they make their profits and
the rest of the people they get into the
market they buy their stocks and
everything starts to fall apart and out
in Britain there was a report that was
conducted over two years an
investigation into the intergenerational
fairness in Britain and the think tank
Resolution Foundation which was directed
by former University's Minister David
Willetts the
team discovered that overpriced homes in
Britain had forced Millennials into
increasingly cramped and expensive
rented properties that leave them with a
longer commute and little chance for
saving for a home and it shows that the
homeownership is collapsing there and
there's a problem in Canada there's a
problem in the United States is a
problem throughout Europe the whole

United States the US economic expansion
now becomes the outright second longest
in history with data going back over a

and thirty-four business cycles
according to Deutsche Bank's calculation
a hundred and seven months the current

they're not expecting to have any type

we're not going to have anything until
December 31st 2028 now think about this
for a second they're trying to tell us
that this economy is so strong that
everything is so great
that everyone's getting jobs that we're
not going to have anything go wrong for

right now you know that they're gonna be

whenever you ever seen a cycle go that
